newsitem.title: FRANCE: French agro-food trade surplus hits all-time high.
newsitem.headline: French agro-food trade surplus hits all-time high.

text.p: France's agro-food trade surplus hit an all-time high in 1996, mostly driven by a sharp rise in wine and spirits and grain exports, the latest statistics from the French centre for external commerce CFCE showed.
The agro-food trade surplus jumped to 58.5 billion francs in 1996 from 53.3 billion in 1995.
The 1996 surplus beat a previous record set in 1993 of 57.1 billion francs, CFCE said in a statement,
Total agro-food exports rose 2.2 percent to 213.6 billion francs while imports eased 0.3 percent to 155.1 billion francs.
Trade in wine and spirits yielded a surplus of 31.2 billion francs, up five percent over 1995.

The scare over so-called mad cow disease hit beef imports more sharply than exports, resulting in a trade surplus of 800 million francs in 1996. This compares with a trade deficit of 400 million in 1995.
Strong exports during the last quarter, notably to countries outside the European Union, pushed the grain trade surplus to 24.7 billion francs in 1996 from 24.3 billion in 1995.
The surplus generated by oilseeds trade jumped 30 percent to 2.6 billion francs.
The coffee trade deficit fell to 4.2 billion francs from 5.5 billion in 1995.
The trade surplus with the European Union jumped four percent to 43.7 billion francs, helped mostly by a 1.3 percent decline in imports.
